<p> On April 23, 1982, Key West seceded from the United States, and the Conch Republic was born. The story goes that the U.S. Border Patrol set up a roadblock on one of the two roads that connects the archipelago to the mainland, causing a 17-mile traffic jam on the island. Seeing this act as a threat to their livelihood and the tourism industry, Key West residents protested. However, they didn’t use banners, signs and marches – they seceded.</p>

            <p>Well, not officially.</p>

            <p>Key West Mayor Dennis Wardlow declared the secession as more of a joke than an

              

              actual act of treason. And while the actual “revolution” lasted only a minute, the

              

              festivities surrounding the Conch Republic Independence Day are on their 34th year,

              

              driven by the republic’s mission to “bring humor, warmth and respect.” In Conch,

              

              that translates to making almost everything a good-humored joke on politics and

              

              patriotism.</p>

            <p>That being said, Conch Republic residents never miss an opportunity to exhibit their

              

              “sovereign state of mind.” The usual festivities for the Conch Republic Independence

              

              Celebration <a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/1032923240084229/" target="_blank">kick off with a party</a> at the <a href="http://www.schoonerwharf.com/" target="_blank">Schooner Wharf Bar</a>, the officially “unofficial”

              

              bar of the Conch Republic, aka where the majority of the after-parties are held.

              

              Other events include the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/1171204672904755/" target="_blank">Wreckers Race</a> at sunset along Mallory Square, a conch

              

              blowing contest and the historic Great Sea Battle with water guns, stale bread and

              

              cannons. The Conch Republic also believes strongly in honoring their heroes, with

              

              such events as the 5-Shot Rum Salute or the World’s Longest Parade.</p>

              <div class="post-image-holder"><img src="/images/blog/conch-2.jpg" alt="Unofficially, the Most Fun in Key West: Conch Republic Independence Celebration"/></div>

            <p>Other worthwhile activities include the Red Ribbon Bed Race, a more elaborate

              

              soap-box derby race down Key West’s main drag, Duval Street. Touted as the most

              

              fun you can have in bed with your clothes on, teams dress up beds-on- wheels and

              

              compete for the fastest time.</p>

            <p>Not to be outdone are the Drag Races, yes, literally “drag” races. Men from all walks

              

              of life stuff their shirts, dawn crazy-colored wigs and scant around in tight, short

              

              skirts, all while racing to complete an obstacle course filled with tires, shopping

              

              carts and tightropes down Duval.</p>

            <p>So pack your costumes, grab a bottle of rum and “secede where others failed.” Get to

              

              the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/The-Conch-Republic-380342204001/timeline" target="_blank">Conch Republic Independence Celebration</a> from April 22 to May 1, 2016, and

              

              stay at the <a href="https://bookings.ihotelier.com/24-North-Hotel-Key-West/bookings.jsp?hotelId=98358" target="_blank">24 North Hotel</a>, the “unofficial” hotel of the Conch Republic. We’re located

              

              about 10 minutes from all the festivities.</p>
